comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: E Rowlands - Sydney (wooden cases) Mr. Evan Rowlands (1826-1894) was a pioneer in the aerated water trade in Australia. He began in Melbourne, eventually expanding to Sydney where he built a large factory at a cost of £15,000, at the corner of Burns and Little Hay Streets, Darling Harbour. Pure water was essential to the product, and a fine spring of water was discovered at Katoomba, in the Blue Mountains, and the site was leased from the government. The water was brought to Sydney by rail. —More from the Bottle College. Mr Rowlands died in 1894 but his company continued until well after the Second World War, when it was sold to Schweppes.[1]
